statement.tex: \\ \text{Which of the following shows the}\\ \text{mathematically correct way to start solving?}
\\ \text{If }g(x) = (\sin x)^{x},\text{ then which of the following}\\ \text{shows the correct evaluation of }g'(x)?

options.tex: \begin{align} f(x) & = (\sin x)^{x} + \sin^{-1} {\sqrt x} \\ \implies \log f(x) & = \log [ (\sin x)^{x}] + \log (\sin^{-1} {\sqrt x}) \\ & = x \cdot \log ( \sin x )+ \log (\sin^{-1} {\sqrt x}) \\ \end{align}\\ \therefore f'(x) = \frac{d}{dx}x \cdot \log ( \sin x )+ \frac{d}{dx}[\log (\sin^{-1} {\sqrt x}) ]

\begin{align} g(x) &= (\sin x)^{x}\\ \implies \log g(x) &= x \cdot \log (\sin x) \\ \end{align}\\
\therefore \frac{1}{g(x)} g'(x) = \underbrace{\left[ x \frac{d}{dx}\log(\sin x) + \log(\sin x) \frac{d}{dx} x\right ]}_{\textbf{Product Rule}} \\
\quad \quad \, = \left[ \underbrace{x\frac{d \log(\sin x)}{d\sin x }\cdot \frac {d \sin x}{dx}}_{\textbf{Chain Rule}} + \log (\sin x ) \frac{d}{dx}x\right] \\
\implies g'(x) = (\sin x)^{x} \left[ x \cdot \cot x + \log (\sin x)\right]
